Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube Building Blocks: Collaborative Proposal: An Expanded Implementation of Cloud-Hosted Real-Time Data Services for the Geosciences (CHORDS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
While advances in sensing, hardware and wireless communications are permitting for previously unmeasured phenomena to be observed across unprecedented scales, it is the ability to act on these data that promises to transform modern geoscientific experimentation. The importance of real-time scientific data (data that are used as soon as they are collected) is ever increasing, particularly in mission critical scenarios, where informed decisions must be made rapidly. Many of the phenomenon occurring within the geosciences can benefit from better coverage of real-time data. Geosciences phenomenon range from hurricanes and severe weather, to earthquakes, volcano eruptions and floods and real-time data are essential to understand these phenomena and predict their impacts. The National Science Foundation funds many small teams of researchers that reside at Universities whose measurements can be of benefit to a better understanding of these phenomenon in order to ultimately improve forecasts and predictions. This is where Cloud-Hosted Real-time Data Services for the Geosciences, or CHORDS, fits in.

CHORDS makes it simple for small research teams to make their real-time data available to the research community in standard formats. By following a few simple steps, a CHORDS ?portal? can be created for a research team and their data can be streamed into it very easily. CHORDS can also be used to access data from large NSF research platforms like radars, aircraft, ships and operational networks of sophisticated instrumentation. Once these data are ingested by a CHORDS portal, they are exposed in standard formats and are available to complex scientific tools such as prediction models and other analysis or decision-support systems. Since the CHORDS concept will be exposed to small research teams at Universities, this will allow college students to learn about the importance of real-time data and how to incorporate these data into their analysis. By having more and higher quality measurements available thorough CHORDS, models and other tools can make more accurate forecasts and provide better-informed decisions to mitigate the impacts and improve the understanding of these phenomenon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our society has  We have all seen the increased number of sensors in everyday objects like cars, homes and handheld devices. The Cloud-Hosted Real-time Data Services for the Geosciences (CHORDS, see chordsrt.com) project harnesses this revolution in sensor technology in the earth sciences. Much like nerve endings in a body, sensors positioned around the world help scientists understand the current state of the earth’s health. Some of these earth sensors are operated by major national labs, while other, low-cost sensors are operated by smaller teams of scientists. The sensors sample data at regular intervals and can be used to make timely decisions when their readings are sent for analysis in real-time. In the case of rapidly changing earth hazards like volcanos, severe weather or flooding, having access to these data as soon as possible becomes crucial to our ability to effectively warn the public of rapidly changing conditions or an impending disaster.

 

Developing software to sample sensor systems on one’s own can be expensive, cumbersome and difficult. CHORDS greatly simplifies the acquisition of data from these sensors by allowing scientists to build a free, simple application in the cloud and using a web interface to sample, collect and monitor sensor data. Over the course of the project, our team focused on developing a general purpose tool that could be adapted for use by a whole range of sensors in the atmospheric, hydrology and solid earth sciences. CHORDS also adheres to science standards so that there is consistency across the data being sampled. This way, scientists can easily understand and interpret the data for analysis purposes. Over the course of the project, we successfully enlisted scientists across these disciplines and connected their data streams into their own CHORDS instances.

 

The CHORDS project proved that sensor data from across the sciences could be served by a common tool which allows easy access to sensor data from the web. CHORDS instances in the atmospheric, hydrology and solid earth sciences have sampled hundreds of millions of earth sensor data points and continue to provide easy and simple access to these data in real-time. The tool is freely available and continues to sample additional sensors being developed by small teams of scientists around the world.
